description: Borrowed from Latin synecdochē, from Ancient Greek συνεκδοχή (sunekdokhḗ, “receiving together”) from σύν (sún, “with”) + ἐκ (ek, “out of”) + δέχεσθαι (dékhesthai, “to accept”), this last element related to δοκέω (dokéō, “to think, suppose, seem”).

entries.meaning: (rhetoric) A figure of speech that uses the name of a part of something to represent the whole, or the whole to represent a part.
examples: Hyponyms: pars pro toto, totum pro parte

entries.meaning: (rhetoric) The use of this figure of speech.
